question: The minimum radar separation to be provided to aircraft established on the localizer course shall be:

choices.choice: 2.0NM between aircraft on adjacent localizer course
2.5NM between aircraft on the same localizer course
5.0NM between aircraft on the same localizer course

explanation:
ILS Localizer Separation

  • When two (or more) aircraft are established on the same ILS localizer course and are within 10 NM of the runway threshold, the radar separation standard may be reduced to 2.5 NM between the aircraft on the radar display.

This reduced separation is allowed under controlled conditions to increase efficiency during approach operations, while still maintaining safety.
subject: Regulations

question: Unless otherwise prescribed by the appropriate ATS authority, the horizontal radar separation minimum prescribed by ICAO shall be:

choices.choice: 3.5NM
8 NM
5.0NM

explanation:
• Standard Horizontal Separation:
    • The general horizontal separation minimum based on radar, ADS-B, or MLAT systems is 9.3 km (5.0 NM).
  • Permissible Reductions in Separation:
    • The radar separation minimum may be reduced by the appropriate ATS authority, but not below: a) 5.6 km (3.0 NM) when radar and/or ADS-B and/or MLAT capabilities at a given location permit. b) 4.6 km (2.5 NM) between succeeding aircraft on the same final approach track within 18.5 km (10 NM) of the runway threshold. A reduced separation of 2.5 NM may be applied if local conditions allow for such reduction.
subject: Regulations

question: Where ADS-B is used for identification, aircraft may be identified by the following procedure:

choices.choice: Asking him to sqwuak assigned mode A code C.
Direct recognition of the aircraft identification in an ADS-B label.
Recognition of an assigned discrete code, the setting of which has been verified.

explanation:
ADS-B Identification Procedures. Where ADS-B is used for identification, aircraft may be identified by one or more of the following procedures:
a) direct recognition of the aircraft identification in an ADS-B label;

b) transfer of ADS-B identification;

c) observation of compliance with an instruction to TRANSMIT ADS-B IDENT;
subject: Regulations

question: An aircraft is considered to be maintaining its assigned level as long as the SSR mode C derived level information indicated that it is within:

choices.choice: +/-500ft of the assigned level in non RVSM airspace
+/-200ft of the assigned level in RVSM airspace
+/-300ft of the assigned level in RVSM airspace

explanation: The tolerance value used to determine that pressure-altitude-derived level information displayed to the controller is accurate shall be ±60 m ( 200 ft) in RVSM airspace. In other airspace, it shall be 90 m (300 ft), except that the appropriate ATS authority may specify a smaller criterion, but not less than ±60 m ( 200 ft), if this is found to be more practical. Geometric height information shall not be used for separation.
subject: Regulations

question: An aircraft in climb or descent is considered to have crossed a level when the SSR mode C derived level information indicates that it has passed this level in the required direction by:

choices.choice: More than 300ft
300ft

explanation:
Passing a Level with Mode C:

  • Mode C is a transponder feature that provides aircraft altitude information to Air Traffic Control (ATC).
  • When Mode C indicates that an aircraft is within 300 feet of a specified altitude (level) during a climb or descent, it is considered to be passing that level.
subject: Regulations

question: Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR) information may be used alone in the provision of separation between aircraft provided;

choices.choice: Instructions to pilot are acknowledged by him by making specific maneuver(s).
Aircraft identification is established and maintained by use of discrete SSR codes.
It can not be used for providing separation

explanation: Use of SSR without primary radar. Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR) information may be used alone in the provision of separation between aircraft provided; aircraft identification is established and maintained by use of discrete SSR codes.
subject: Regulations

question: Radar identification of a departing aircraft can be achieved if a radar blip is observed within a certain distance from the end of the runway. Identification has to be achieved within:

choices.choice: 1NM
3NM
5NM

explanation:
Departing Aircraft Method:
By correlating an observed radar position indication with an aircraft which is known to have just departed, provided that the identification is established within 1 NM from the end of the runway used. Particular care should be taken to avoid confusion with aircraft holding over or overflying the aerodrome, or with aircraft departing from or making a missed approach over adjacent runways.
subject: Regulations

question: Separation based on the use of MLAT position symbols and PSR blips shall be applied so that

choices.choice: the distance between the centres of the position symbols and PSR blips, representing the positions of the aircraft concerned, is never less than a prescribed minimum.
the distance between the edges of the position symbols and PSR blips, representing the positions of the aircraft concerned, is never less than a prescribed minimum.
the distance between the furthest edges of the position symbols and PSR blips, representing the positions of the aircraft concerned, is never more than a prescribed minimum.

explanation:
Multilateration is the use of mathematical calculations to derive positions for aircraft that are not yet transmitting their exact position via ADS-B. By using multilateration, or “MLAT” for short, we can determine the positions of many more aircraft than we would otherwise be able to track.

PSR IDENTIFICATION 
Position Report Method:
By correlating a particular radar position indication with an aircraft reporting its position over or as bearing and distance from, a point shown on the situation display; and by ascertaining that the track of the particular radar position is consistent with the aircraft path or reported heading.
subject: Regulations

question: The aircraft control unit has reported “radar contact”. What does that mean to the pilot?

choices.choice: The aircraft is subject to positive control
position reports may be omitted
The radar identify of the aircraft has been established

explanation: In aviation, “radar contact” is a term used by Air Traffic Control (ATC) to inform a pilot that the aircraft has been identified on the radar display and is being tracked by the radar system. Once radar contact is established, ATC can monitor the aircraft’s position, altitude, and movement.
subject: Regulations

question: When a RADAR operators says the following to an aircraft:

choices.choice: 030° magnetic in still air conditions (thereby flying the magnetic track)
030° compass in still air conditions (thereby flying the compass heading)
030° true, in still air conditions (thereby flying the true track)

subject: Regulations

question: Which code shall be used on Mode “A” to provide recognition of an aircraft subjected to unlawful interference?

choices.choice: Code 7700
Code 7600
Code 7500

explanation:
Mode A transponder codes used in aviation for specific emergency situations:

  • 7700: General Emergency (used to indicate any kind of emergency on board)
  • 7600: Radio Communication Failure (loss of communication with ATC)
  • 7500: Unlawful Interference (such as hijacking or other security threats)
subject: Regulations

question: Upon intercepting the assigned radial, the controller advises you that you are on the airway and to “resume own navigation”. This phrase means that:

choices.choice: radar services are terminated and you will be responsible for position reports
You are to assume responsibility for your own navigation
You are to contact the center at the next reporting point

explanation: Resume Own Navigation Used by ATC to advise a pilot to resume his/her own navigational responsibility. It is issued after completion of a radar vector or when radar contact is lost while the aircraft is being radar vectored.
subject: Regulations

question: What does the ATC term “radar contact” signify?

choices.choice: Your aircraft has been identified on the radar display and radar flight instructions will be provided until radar identification is terminated
You will be given traffic advisories until advised that the service has been terminated or that radar contact has been lost.
ATC is receiving your transponder and will furnish vectors and traffic advisories until you are advised that contact has been lost.

explanation: Used by ATC to inform an aircraft that it is identified on the radar display and radar flight following will be provided until radar identification is terminated. Radar service may also be provided within the limits of necessity and capability. When a pilot is informed of “radar contact,” he/she automatically discontinues reporting over compulsory reporting points.
subject: Regulations

question: Where a “Secondary Surveillance Radar” (SSR) is not available, radar identification may be achieved by one of the following procedures:

choices.choice: To instruct pilot to execute one or more changes of 10°
To instruct the pilot to execute one or more changes of 45°
To instruct the pilot to execute one or more changes of 30° or more

explanation:
Radar Identification without SSR:

  • The controller may instruct the pilot to execute one or more heading changes of 30° or more and observe the movement on the radar screen. This allows the radar controller to establish which radar target corresponds to the aircraft being controlled.
  • Other methods include:
    • Identification based on an aircraft’s position relative to a known point or a fix.
    • Observing an aircraft’s departure from an airport when its expected track can be predicted.
subject: Regulations

question: When “Secondary Radar” is used, an aircraft may be identified by one of the following procedures:

choices.choice: To request pilot to set transponder on position "OFF"
To request pilot to switch form "ON" to "STBY"
Observation of compliance with an instruction to operate transponder from "ON" to "STBY" and back to "ON"

explanation:
• Transponder Identification Procedures:
    • When using SSR, a controller can instruct the pilot to set the transponder to “STBY” (standby) from “ON” and then back to “ON.”
    • The controller observes the corresponding changes in the radar display to confirm the identification of the aircraft.
  • Detailed Procedures:
    • The identification is established by observing the transponder response when the pilot complies with the instructions.
    • This method confirms that the aircraft being monitored corresponds to the specific transponder code.
subject: Regulations

question: The Air Traffic Control Services: do not prevent collisions with terrain.

choices.choice: Wrong, they do prevent collisions with terrain
Except when an aircraft is flying IFR in IMC
Correct, except when an IFR flight is vectored by radar

subject: Regulations

question: Which code shall be used on mode “A” to provide recognition of an emergency aircraft?

choices.choice: Code 7600
Code 7500
Code 7700

explanation:
Mode A transponder codes used in aviation for specific emergency situations:

  • 7700: General Emergency (used to indicate any kind of emergency on board)
  • 7600: Radio Communication Failure (loss of communication with ATC)
  • 7500: Unlawful Interference (such as hijacking or other security threats)
subject: Regulations

question: One of the functions ensured by a radar control unit for the provision of approach control service is:

choices.choice: To conduct surveillance radar approaches
To apply a horizontal separation less than 5NM
To provide instructions in order to reduce separations minima, if accepted by the pilots.

explanation:
One of the key functions of a radar control unit in providing approach control services is to conduct surveillance radar approaches (SRA). This involves using radar to guide aircraft safely to the runway by providing headings, altitudes, and distance information.

While radar can be used to maintain separation between aircraft, applying less than 5 NM horizontal separation or reducing separation minima typically requires specific conditions and regulations, not pilot acceptance alone.
subject: Regulations

question: The primary duty provided by a radar unit is:

choices.choice: To assist aircraft on the location of storms
To provide radar separation
To assist aircraft where navigation appears unsatisfactory

explanation: The primary duty of a radar unit is to provide radar separation between aircraft to ensure safe distances are maintained. While radar units can also assist with navigation or alert pilots to weather conditions like storms, their main responsibility is to maintain safe separation between aircraft, ensuring that conflicts or collisions are avoided.
subject: Regulations

question: What is meant when departure control instructions you to “resume own navigation” after you have been vectored to an airway?

choices.choice: Advisors will no longer be issued by ATC
You are still in radar contact, but must make position reports
You should maintain that airway by use of your navigation equipment

explanation:
• “Resume own navigation” is used when ATC has completed radar vectoring and the aircraft is directed to return to its original flight plan route or to follow a designated airway.
  • The aircraft remains under ATC supervision, but the responsibility for course navigation shifts back to the pilot.
subject: Regulations

question: All aircraft carrying serviceable transponder shall operate the transponder:

choices.choice: At all times during flight, regardless of whether the aircraft is within or outside airspace where SSR is used for ATS purposes.
Only when the aircraft is flying within airspace where SSR is used for ATS purposes.
As and when required by the pilot.

explanation:
• Transponder Operation: Aircraft equipped with a serviceable SSR transponder must operate it at all times, regardless of the type of airspace. This ensures that ATC and other aircraft can detect and identify the aircraft using SSR or Traffic Collision Avoidance Systems (TCAS).
  • Visibility for ATS: Even in airspace where SSR is not actively used for ATS purposes, the transponder must be operated to assist with safety and surveillance.
  • ATC Instructions: ATC may instruct pilots to switch transponder modes (e.g., STANDBY or IDENT) as necessary, but the default operation is to keep the transponder active.
subject: Regulations
